<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning and Happy July 4th. </strong>I recently learned from Bloomberg editor David Shipley that the American citizenship test wasn’t standardized until the 1950s, and before that aspiring citizens were quizzed on their understanding of American history by a judge. It was...pretty hard. Here are several questions you might’ve been asked to become an American citizen in 1944. How would you do? Answers at the bottom of the email.</p>
<ol style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>Which of the following states seceded during the Civil War? Florida, Maryland, Delaware, Kentucky</span></li>
<li>
<span>Which of these cities has </span><span><em>not </em></span><span>been a capital of the US? NYC, Boston, Princeton, Philadelphia</span>
</li>
<li><span>Where must all bills intended to raise revenue originate? Popular referendum, the House, the Senate, the president</span></li>
<li>
<span>Which was </span><span><em>not </em></span><span>one of the original 13 colonies? South Carolina, Massachusetts, Georgia, Maine</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Beeple
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/icebreakers-withbeeple?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Picture of the digital artist Beeple" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjU3L3BpY3R1cmVfb2ZfYmVlcGxlLkpQRyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Brandon Todd/WENEW</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you’ve read about non-fungible tokens at all this year, you’re probably familiar with the person we interviewed this week: Mike Winkelmann, better known as Beeple. He made history and a million headlines when he sold an NFT of his digital art for $69 million at auction in March. It’s still the most expensive NFT ever sold.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We chatted with Winkelmann about NFT 101, the future of the technology, and his new platform, WENEW, which is currently auctioning its first NFT: <a href="https://we.new/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the moment</a> Andy Murray won Wimbledon in 2013.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How would you describe NFTs to someone who doesn’t understand them?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s a digital certificate of ownership that’s backed by the blockchain. So you can prove that you are the true owner of something, the only owner of it. It can be applied to a bunch of different things: digital art, the collectibles that we’re building with WENEW, and it can also be applied to physical objects to help prove ownership. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Why do you think people have a hard time wrapping their heads around the concept?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Because it’s not a concept that we're used to on computers. We're used to being able to copy things infinitely, and all the copies are exactly the same and you have no idea where the original came from. There's no way to trace it back. An NFT is fundamentally different. The other thing that is tough for people to understand is that one of the main aspects of ownership with many things is being able to restrict access to that thing. And that's not a part of NFTs.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is the future of NFTs?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You're going to see a bunch of use cases, and we're very, very early with this. It’s analogous to the very early days of the internet when people were trying to figure out the best use cases for a webpage. Because a webpage is really just a blank page, and you can put whatever you want on it—some of those things are entertaining and some of those things are useful.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This WENEW project is one new use case for NFTs. As more use cases come, more people will learn about this technology and see value in it for something that connects to their lives. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Do you think NFTs will hold the general public's interest, or will they be more of a niche hobby? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I think it will be somewhat analogous to email in that you won’t choose whether you like it or not, or believe in it or not...NFTs will be part of your life, just because they'll be the easiest way to prove that you own things. They’ll be attached to your car, your phone, your house, your diploma. They’ll be attached to a bunch of different things that make it easy to prove that you are the one single person that has that thing. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You’ve had quite a year, selling an NFT for $69 million. What’s been the most exciting part? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It's been really exciting to be a part of something that feels like it's the beginning. I actually asked Mark Cuban a few months ago, “Is this what it was like at the beginning of the internet?” And he's like, “This is literally exactly what it was like.” Everybody's building things and everybody's pushing in different directions, and it gives you ideas for your projects. It’s a super exciting time, and I feel very honored to be a part of that.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>

WORK LIFE

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
</h1>
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reader-submitted questions</a> about work in 2021. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Hey Kate, I recently discovered that I am being paid 25%–33% less than my male colleagues working in the same position with the same level of education and work experience. I am the only female in my role, so this has me feeling pretty uncomfortable and discouraged. Do you have any recommendations on how best to handle this situation?—Anita     </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Anita, my advice would be to first do some deep digging on the source of the pay gap you’ve identified. Did the discrepancy originate when you joined the company? Is it because of inconsistencies from missing out on raises over the years? </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Once you’re armed with this info, the next step is to speak up and raise the issue with your manager. But be conscious of timing. If your company has a promotion or a raise cycle, that would be a great time to bring this up. Another good time to talk about compensation is when you feel like you’re crushing it at your job—for instance, right after the completion of a successful project you led. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">When you speak to your manager, they’ll be expecting you to explain why you believe an increase in salary is merited at this point in time. Do market research of current salary ranges and create a loose script for yourself. Be clear, specific, and confident! </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">If you don’t get a positive response, maybe it’s time to look for an employer that values your talents and experience. I hear many are hiring…</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Ask Kate here</em></a><em>.</em></p>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>

</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Origin Stories: July Fourth’s Favorite Companies
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/origin-stories-july-fourths-favorite-companies?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="NEW YORK, NY - JULY 04:  Matt Stonie, Joey Chestnut, and Carmen Cincotti" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjU5LzIwMThfbmF0aGFuX3NfZmFtb3VzX2hvdF9kb2dfZWF0aW5nX2NvbnRlc3QuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Steven Ferdman/Getty Images</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Why is Nathan's the first name you think of when you picture a hot dog? What’s up with the matching Old Navy shirts in every single one of our family pics? And why does beer taste better once you pour it into a red Solo cup?</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Since July 4th is all about celebrating history, let’s go back in time and dive into the origin stories of the companies and products we most associate with the holiday. </p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Red Solo Cup</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s the early 1930s in Chicago, and disposable cups are all the rage after the city council banned the use of germy “common drinking cups” 20 years before. Leo Hulseman decides to leave his job as a salesman for the soon-to-be Dixie Cup Company to start his own business, Paper Container Manufacturing, selling paper drinking cones. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Hulseman then made a big decision that would forever change the college party scene: He bought an automatic paper cone-making machine from George Method Merta, a Czechoslovakian immigrant and inventor, whose wife, Bozena Merta, suggested they call the single-use cups “solo” cups.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It wasn’t until the ’70s that Leo’s son, Robert, launched the plastic cup we know and love today with the original colors of red, blue, yellow, and peach. In 2012, Solo was acquired by Dart Container for $1 billion, and according to the company’s website, fans now post 400,000+ photos with the iconic red cup every year.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left"><strong>Nathan’s Hot Dogs</strong></h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yes, a guy named Nathan did actually start this company. In 1916, Nathan Handwerker began selling hot dogs in New York’s Coney Island for five cents. In fact, you can still visit the original location and order a hot dog and fried frog legs, a staple on the menu since the 1950s.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">According to wiener lore, the July 4th hot dog-eating contest that bears Nathan’s name was unofficially founded the same year the restaurant was founded in 1916, but the first official records put the competition’s start date at 1967. The contest, where competitors have 10 minutes to inhale as many hot dogs as they can, has aired live on ESPN since 2004.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>The defending men’s champ is Joey Chestnut, who ate 75 dogs in 10 minutes last year, and the reigning women’s champ is Miki Sudo, who downed 48.5. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Nathan’s trades on the NASDAQ under the ticker NATH, and while its symbol definitely should have been HDOG, you can’t argue with a 30% year-to-date increase.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left"><strong>Old Navy</strong></h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s hard to complete the Fourth of July look without the perfect, distressed flag T-shirt. In 1994, Old Navy opened its first stores in Northern California and stocked its shelves with low-priced graphic tees featuring the company’s American flag design.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It took a few years for the company to realize that people were buying the shirts for their families and <a href="https://fashionista.com/2017/07/old-navy-4th-of-july-shirts-phenomenon?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">scheduling family photos</a> around them, but it probably contributed to the retailer’s growth that shot up like an illegal roman candle. Old Navy became the first clothing company to reach $1 billion in sales in its first four years of business.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In 2019, Old Navy owner Gap Inc. <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/16/business/gap-old-navy-split/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made a plan</a> to spin it off as its own company. But it scrapped the spinoff in January 2020 following a few months of struggling sales at Old Navy and the departure of Gap CEO Art Peck, the plan’s main architect. </p>

Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that wants you to feel like the fifth Jonas Brother (don’t forget Frankie, the most important Jonas). We’ll give you a few facts about a listing, and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/glbJfTWbxrCz38Rruw/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="15,000 square-foot home in the Encino neighborhood in LA, California" data-source="Redfin" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Redfin</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Funny enough, the sellers for today’s <a href="https://www.dirt.com/gallery/entertainers/actors/joe-jonas-sophie-turner-house-encino-1203388269/joejonas_enc/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">property</a> are Joe Jonas and Sophie Turner. Located in the Encino neighborhood of LA, this 15,000-square-foot home is situated on almost an acre of land and has three powder rooms, which is what rich people call the tiny bathroom you might have for guests and hiding during parties. Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>9 beds, 9.5 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>A glass wall in the family room that opens to the backyard</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Twinkling donut chandelier in the master bedroom</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>A kitchen island with precisely one million seats</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much to own a piece of Jo Bro history? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

NYC, Boston, Princeton, Philadelphia\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhere must all bills intended to raise revenue originate? background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIcebreakers With...Beeple\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/icebreakers-withbeeple?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Picture of the digital artist Beeple\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjU3L3BpY3R1cmVfb2ZfYmVlcGxlLkpQRyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eBrandon Todd/WENEW\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you’ve read about non-fungible tokens at all this year, you’re probably familiar with the person we interviewed this week: Mike Winkelmann, better known as Beeple. He made history and a million headlines when he sold an NFT of his digital art for $69 million at auction in March. It’s still the most expensive NFT ever sold.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe chatted with Winkelmann about NFT 101, the future of the technology, and his new platform, WENEW, which is currently auctioning its first NFT: \u003ca href=\"https://we.new/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe moment\u003c/a\u003e Andy Murray won Wimbledon in 2013.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow would you describe NFTs to someone who doesn’t understand them?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s a digital certificate of ownership that’s backed by the blockchain. So you can prove that you are the true owner of something, the only owner of it. It can be applied to a bunch of different things: digital art, the collectibles that we’re building with WENEW, and it can also be applied to physical objects to help prove ownership. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy do you think people have a hard time wrapping their heads around the concept?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBecause it’s not a concept that we're used to on computers. We're used to being able to copy things infinitely, and all the copies are exactly the same and you have no idea where the original came from. There's no way to trace it back. An NFT is fundamentally different. The other thing that is tough for people to understand is that one of the main aspects of ownership with many things is being able to restrict access to that thing. And that's not a part of NFTs.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is the future of NFTs?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou're going to see a bunch of use cases, and we're very, very early with this. It’s analogous to the very early days of the internet when people were trying to figure out the best use cases for a webpage. Because a webpage is really just a blank page, and you can put whatever you want on it—some of those things are entertaining and some of those things are useful.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis WENEW project is one new use case for NFTs. As more use cases come, more people will learn about this technology and see value in it for something that connects to their lives. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you think NFTs will hold the general public's interest, or will they be more of a niche hobby? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI think it will be somewhat analogous to email in that you won’t choose whether you like it or not, or believe in it or not...NFTs will be part of your life, just because they'll be the easiest way to prove that you own things. They’ll be attached to your car, your phone, your house, your diploma. They’ll be attached to a bunch of different things that make it easy to prove that you are the one single person that has that thing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou’ve had quite a year, selling an NFT for $69 million. What’s been the most exciting part? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt's been really exciting to be a part of something that feels like it's the beginning. I actually asked Mark Cuban a few months ago, “Is this what it was like at the beginning of the internet?” And he's like, “This is literally exactly what it was like.” Everybody's building things and everybody's pushing in different directions, and it gives you ideas for your projects. It’s a super exciting time, and I feel very honored to be a part of that.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F02%2Ficebreakers-withbeeple\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereader-submitted questions\u003c/a\u003e about work in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHey Kate, I recently discovered that I am being paid 25%–33% less than my male colleagues working in the same position with the same level of education and work experience. I am the only female in my role, so this has me feeling pretty uncomfortable and discouraged. Do you have any recommendations on how best to handle this situation?—Anita     \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnita, my advice would be to first do some deep digging on the source of the pay gap you’ve identified. Did the discrepancy originate when you joined the company? Is it because of inconsistencies from missing out on raises over the years? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOnce you’re armed with this info, the next step is to speak up and raise the issue with your manager. But be conscious of timing. If your company has a promotion or a raise cycle, that would be a great time to bring this up. Another good time to talk about compensation is when you feel like you’re crushing it at your job—for instance, right after the completion of a successful project you led. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhen you speak to your manager, they’ll be expecting you to explain why you believe an increase in salary is merited at this point in time. Do market research of current salary ranges and create a loose script for yourself. Be clear, specific, and confident! \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIf you don’t get a positive response, maybe it’s time to look for an employer that values your talents and experience. I hear many are hiring…\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAsk Kate here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F02%2Fmake-work-address-pay-gap-issue\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nOrigin Stories: July Fourth’s Favorite Companies\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/origin-stories-july-fourths-favorite-companies?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"NEW YORK, NY - JULY 04:  Matt Stonie, Joey Chestnut, and Carmen Cincotti\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjU5LzIwMThfbmF0aGFuX3NfZmFtb3VzX2hvdF9kb2dfZWF0aW5nX2NvbnRlc3QuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eSteven Ferdman/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhy is Nathan's the first name you think of when you picture a hot dog? What’s up with the matching Old Navy shirts in every single one of our family pics? And why does beer taste better once you pour it into a red Solo cup?\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSince July 4th is all about celebrating history, let’s go back in time and dive into the origin stories of the companies and products we most associate with the holiday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eRed Solo Cup\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s the early 1930s in Chicago, and disposable cups are all the rage after the city council banned the use of germy “common drinking cups” 20 years before. Leo Hulseman decides to leave his job as a salesman for the soon-to-be Dixie Cup Company to start his own business, Paper Container Manufacturing, selling paper drinking cones. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHulseman then made a big decision that would forever change the college party scene: He bought an automatic paper cone-making machine from George Method Merta, a Czechoslovakian immigrant and inventor, whose wife, Bozena Merta, suggested they call the single-use cups “solo” cups.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt wasn’t until the ’70s that Leo’s son, Robert, launched the plastic cup we know and love today with the original colors of red, blue, yellow, and peach. In 2012, Solo was acquired by Dart Container for $1 billion, and according to the company’s website, fans now post 400,000+ photos with the iconic red cup every year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNathan’s Hot Dogs\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYes, a guy named Nathan did actually start this company. In 1916, Nathan Handwerker began selling hot dogs in New York’s Coney Island for five cents. In fact, you can still visit the original location and order a hot dog and fried frog legs, a staple on the menu since the 1950s.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAccording to wiener lore, the July 4th hot dog-eating contest that bears Nathan’s name was unofficially founded the same year the restaurant was founded in 1916, but the first official records put the competition’s start date at 1967. The contest, where competitors have 10 minutes to inhale as many hot dogs as they can, has aired live on ESPN since 2004.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe defending men’s champ is Joey Chestnut, who ate 75 dogs in 10 minutes last year, and the reigning women’s champ is Miki Sudo, who downed 48.5. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNathan’s trades on the NASDAQ under the ticker NATH, and while its symbol definitely should have been HDOG, you can’t argue with a 30% year-to-date increase.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOld Navy\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s hard to complete the Fourth of July look without the perfect, distressed flag T-shirt. In 1994, Old Navy opened its first stores in Northern California and stocked its shelves with low-priced graphic tees featuring the company’s American flag design.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt took a few years for the company to realize that people were buying the shirts for their families and \u003ca href=\"https://fashionista.com/2017/07/old-navy-4th-of-july-shirts-phenomenon?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003escheduling family photos\u003c/a\u003e around them, but it probably contributed to the retailer’s growth that shot up like an illegal roman candle. Old Navy became the first clothing company to reach $1 billion in sales in its first four years of business.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn 2019, Old Navy owner Gap Inc. \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/16/business/gap-old-navy-split/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade a plan\u003c/a\u003e to spin it off as its own company. But it scrapped the spinoff in January 2020 following a few months of struggling sales at Old Navy and the departure of Gap CEO Art Peck, the plan’s main architect. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F02%2Forigin-stories-july-fourths-favorite-companies\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
